awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Beyond O/H: Fundamental Astrophysics with HII Region Abundances
awd_abstract_narration:
Galaxies contain gas and stars.  The chemicals in the gas leave fingerprints in the form of emission lines.  The chemical abundances can be measured by studying the emission lines.  These studies show trends between the abundances and the stellar mass of a galaxy.  They also show trends in the abundances between the inner and outer regions of a galaxy.  Such trends carry important clues about how galaxies form and evolve.  But the clues are muddled because the absolute scales for the trends are uncertain.  To make progress, the team will observe galaxies at optical wavelengths with the Large Binocular Telescope.  They will use a new, NSF-enabled instrument to study the galaxies' emission lines.  The team will then analyze the emission lines to determine absolute abundances.  Senior team members will train junior team members.  The team will partner with the State Parks of Minnesota to give public talks in novel settings.  They will also use a planetarium to reach K-12 students in low-income areas of Ohio.

The team will analyze cutting-edge emission line spectra of HII regions in 13 spiral galaxies.  Their goals are to (1) solve the decades-old discrepancy between abundances based on collisionally-excited forbidden lines and those based on optical recombination lines, (2) conduct a definitive study the abundance gradients in spiral galaxies, and (3) design a calibration of strong-line abundances appropriate to both unresolved global spectra and spatially-resolved spectra from the next generation of surveys with integral field units.

por.por_cntn:
The chemical elements heavier than hydrogen and helium are made primarily by nuclear fusion in the centers of massive stars. These stars end their lives in supernova explosions that scatter these newly-maded elements into interstellar space where they become available to become part of the next generation of stars. Each successive generation of stars in a galaxy is thus born with a greater proportion of heavy elements relative to hydrogen than the previous. Our Sun and its planets are relatively rich in heavy elements as a result of this process of galactic chemical evolution.

This project's goal was to gather new data to better understand how these heavy elements are distributed in nearby galaxies by obtaining optical spectra of gaseous nebulae associated with newly-formed stars. Our observations were made with the Multi-Object Double Spectrographs (MODS) on the twin 8.4-meter diameter Large Binocular Telescope (LBT) on Mt. Graham in Arizona. We have measured the amounts of Oxygen, Nitrogen, Carbon, Sulfur, Argon, and Neon, all elements that trace production of these elements in intermediate- and high-mass stars.  We have data from hundreds of nebulae distributed across the faces of about 10 nearby spiral galaxies, allowing us to measure the enrichment patterns of these elements across the galaxies.

We made the following findings:

1) While carbon (C) is one of the most abundant heavy elements after hydrogen and helium, it is notoriously difficult to measure because its visible-light emission lines are so faint.  Our LBT spectra have allowed us to detect these faint C lines, and greatly increase the number of high-quality measurements of the abundance of carbon in nearby galaxies.  In the best galaxy in our study, M101, we find that the carbon-to-hydrogen (C/H) ratio is highest in the middle and falls rapidly as you move outward from the center in the same way as the N/H and O/H ratios.  However, we found that the C/N ratio was consistent with a nearly constant value with a very small scatter, at odds with expectations from assumptions theorists usually make about the different sources of C and N. We have also seen carbon lines in other galaxies in our sample, but we used M101, which has the best data, to first calibrate the many corrections needed to interpret our data and extend the study to other galaxies to see if our C/N results is found elsewhere.

2) We examined relative and absolute abundnaces of O, N, S, Ar, and Ne for 4 spiral galaxies. While they show the usual O/H and other gradients as seen in other spirals, our high-quality data on N/O yielded a surprise: after accounting for differences in the average N/O, the data show that the 4 galaxies have a tight universal N/O gradient: higher N/O in the middle, falling off until finally flattening to a near-constant value. This is telling us something about how nitrogren is produced in intermediate- and high-mass stars, an important new constraint for theorists modeling the chemical evolution of spiral galaxies.

3) The high quality of our new data on galaxies pushed us into regimes where we have had to revisit some of the deeply technical aspects of this work, in particular how we measure gas temperatures in the nebulae we observe, and how we account for effects of gas ionization under different conditions, in order to interpret our results.  The outcome of the study of NGC2403 led us to device refined methods for combining different temperature measurements, leading to improvements of heavy element abundances we measured in earlier studies, and giving us a path to improving our techniques in the future.
